posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

>>14566261
>A Von Neumann probe shouldn't be out of reach even with our limited technology
I think one thing people will increasingly realise over the next 100 or so years is that computers don't last long at all. Bits can flip due to charged particles, which will ruin even a self-replicating self correcting program very quickly when travelling through unprotrcted space. Not to mention that the actual chemical composition of the computer will be changed by ionising radiation over time, which on the small scale of a processor matters a lot. I think it's one of the primary reasons why whenever NASA sends a probe to Mars, a number of the instruments are usually broken on arrival even though they are built and rated to survive the trip.
An interstellar trip is probably not possible with a computer sufficient to rebuild the spacecraft it's on.

>Michelsberg burials reveal a stratified society. In some of the sites—for example, at Bruchsal-Aue near Karlsruhe—a high-status individual lies curled up on his side in traditional LBK fashion, with other individuals thrown in apparently willy-nilly at his feet. The ratio of strontium isotopes in their teeth indicates that all those buried in a single grave were raised on the same diet—a farmer's diet—but their DNA reveals that those surrounding the central figure generally had much higher hunter-gatherer ancestry than him. Additionally, the remains of those with hunter-gatherer ancestry were often discarded in rubbish pits or ditches.

>According to Gronenborn, these findings point to a society that discriminated on both social and biological grounds and one in which little value was attached to the lives of those at the bottom.

>In a 2017 paper, the Bordeaux group reported “probable practices of human sacrifice” at another Michelsberg site, Gougenheim, in Alsace. Significantly, the researchers sequenced mtDNA from the teeth of 22 individuals and found differences between those laid deliberately into graves and those thrown in alongside them in “unconventional” positions. “The individuals in the unconventional position had mitochondrial profiles inherited from hunter-gatherers, while those in the conventional position had not,”

To understand Christianity, you must first understand Judaism and how it began:

One of the transitional stages from polytheism to monotheism has been called henotheism, a situation in which there are many gods but one God prevails as the king of gods or the God of gods. This is how the worship of YHVH emerged, as distinct from the Canaanite worship of El.

Judaism stems from Canaanite polytheism, hence why some descriptions of YHVH are lifted more or less directly from the Ugaritic Ba'al Cycle. YHVH originally had a Goddess consort, Asherah, whose worship was later outlawed
Deuteronomy 16:21
>Do not set up any wooden Asherah pole beside the altar you build to the LORD your God.

Early Jews distinguished themselves from other Canaanites by not worshiping the other Gods of the Canaanite pantheon, instead worshipped YHVH specifically (henotheism) while acknowledging the existence of the other Gods. Over centuries they began to place YHVH in a position which superseded El as the sole God of reality - leading eventually to the development of the Tanakh.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZECezMYug8c [Embed]

So when Jesus claims to be one with YHVH in the NT (John 10:30), it's important to remember that YHVH wasn't originally conceived as the creator God of reality. Make of that what you will.

The people now known as Phoenicians, similar to the neighboring Israelites, Moabites and Edomites, were a Canaanite people. Canaanites are a group of ancient Semitic-speaking peoples that emerged in the Levant in at least the third millennium BC.

Jews & Phoenicians were originally Canaanites, hence why their religious customs stem from Canaanite polytheism.
>What is Asherah called in the LXX?
https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/0966735018794478
Here's an interesting article on her role in the Septuagint. Basically she's described more favorably.
>Is Baal then the creator god?
He was a fertility God, but not the highest God of his pantheon - which was El. Elohim literally means "children of El." YHVH was originally one of these children, until the Jews conflated him with the Canaanite El - making him the "highest God" of their faith.

Yahweh was originally described as one of the sons of El in Deuteronomy 32:8–9, but this was removed by a later emendation to the text.

>>14565545
I'm not sure that it does really, the notion that the gods reflected the life cycle of the king was pretty common.
This is why gods often have a nativity where they are pictured as an infant which is semi-separated from them.
Then are a mature strong figure who defeats his enemies.
Then a wise elder who judges over his sons.

Zeus obviously reflects this cycle, and it seems like Yahweh/El may have already had that duality. With local differences in importance of the various gods determining what specific deity filled that role. But that may just come down to differences in local dialects more than these being actual separate figures.
The Hittites revered dozens of virtually identical gods, the Greeks seem to have done the same thing. Later on those gods got collapsed into single figures, possibly as trade increased, and families of similar languages became parts of a single language community.

Things like "Baal" (Lord) being an acceptable title to give Yahweh for a time may have been a result of that kind of linguistic commonality and growth, with the rejection of it coming from a later period of regression and religious fundamentalism.

If you're interested in Comparative Mythology, look into Chaoskampf, the primordial battle between a storm deity representing order and a serpentine monster representing chaos. YHWH battling Leviathan is a Semitic telling of this story.
>Jormungandr vs Thor (Norse)
>Typhon vs Zeus (Greek)
>Apep vs Ra (Egyptian)
>Tiamat vs Marduk (Mesopotamian)
>Vritra vs Indra (Hindu)
>Yamata no Orochi vs Susanoo (Japanese)

These are either coincidental or retellings of an early story from the Proto-Indo-Europeans. To say that YHWH confronting Leviathan is not similar to these stories is denial.

I suspect part of the reason it's hard to find traces of the dying god motif in the Bible, is that the god of death Mot/Mawet's name is literally Death (mawet), so when the name appears in the Bible it's translated as death (or at best Death), no matter how personified Death/Mot is.
A lot of verses make a lot more sense when you accept the Bible refers to the god Mawet and not just a vague "death" concept.

Psalm 49:13
Like sheep they sink down to Sheol;
Mawet [Death] will be their shepherd;
[KJV has "Death shall feed on them" which seems to be a fair translation of the Hebrew if Mawet is their shepherd it's in the sense that they are his livestock to slaughter]

Job 28:22
Abaddon and Mawet [Destruction and Death] say,
‘With our ears we have heard a report of it.’

Job 30:23
For I know that You will bring me to Mawet [Death], And to the house of meeting for all living.

Psalm 55:15
Let Mawet [Death] seize them; let them go down alive to Sheol, For evil is in their dwelling, in their midst.

And naturally every passage with "redeem from death" or "rescue their souls from death" is actually "redeem from Mawet" and "rescue from Mawet", "turned over to death" is "given over to Mawet"
Deep darkness is always literally "the shadow of Mawet/Death" even in perfectly mundane contexts but most translations only keep the phrase for Psalm 23 ("in the valley of...")

So what kind of god is it who triumps over Mawet or can rescue the souls of the dead from his domain? Well a God like Baal or Osiris, who has escaped the abode of Death himself.

>>14566461
It was written mostly by Moses (Exodus 17:14, 24:4, 34:27-28, Deuteronomy 4:44, 31:9, 31:24-26) who had access to both the tribal tradition of Israel as regards the lives of the patriarchs as well as direct revelation from YHWH. He was atop Mount Sinai forty days and forty nights enveloped in the cloud (Exodus 24:15-18) when he received the tablets of stone; it is reasonable to assume that God relayed much of what is found in Genesis to Moses there, particularly the account of Creation and the antediluvian period.

The section of Deuteronomy 34 is a postscript added by either Joshua, Eleazar the priest, or a later editor, perhaps Samuel or Ezra. But it is ludicrous to assume that the whole Pentateuch was somehow stitched together from different and competing texts by a group of post-exilic scribes and then somehow accepted by the religious majority of Israel. Better to allow a text to explain itself before entertaining notions of alternative origins.

>>14566587
This is a pretty plausible theory taken purely in and of itself.

The problem lies in that such an explanation is explicitly contradicted by the narrative account of Scripture, which relates the repeated apostasy of the Israelites in worshiping gods other than YHWH. More relevant to the discussion is the fact that the Hebrews, even those of the Exodus generation, were disposed towards representing God as being part of the created order (the most famous incident being that of the Golden Calf), in direct violation of His commandments. This explains all of the depictions of YHWH uncovered by archeologists and the reason why He resembles other Canaanite deities; in attempting to syncretize their religion with that of the surrounding pagan culture, the Israelites frequently resorted to linking YHWH with whatever similar deity could be found in a neighbor's pantheon and positing a shared identity between the two. In doing so, they divested God of His exclusivity and were able enjoy a friendly relationship with their neighbors.

Such a theory explains the historical phenomena much more readily than your monotheist revisionist theory, and with the added benefit of having a textual basis. Again, you're welcome to throw out hypotheses, but the lack of definitive evidence that would vindicate such claims as opposed to what Scripture itself says will always make your case one that requires a greater burden of proof, given what we can explain via the Biblical account.

>>14566885
Every modern commentary addresses this issue quite clearly. Chapter 1 is a general narrative of God's creating all that fills the earth, sea, and sky. It is an account that establishes God a prior to anything that can be seen by the human eye, and wholly sovereign over its disposition; He is not merely a participant. Its partially polemical intent explains the broad scope of coverage in days of creation. The narrative reaches its climax, of course, is God's creating man on the sixth day and His resting on the seventh. And everything that He made was good.

Chapter 2 picks up at this pivotal juncture, the creation of man, and narrows its focus so as to describe in detail God's purpose in making mankind in His own image. The flora described in Genesis 2 is specifically those species related to man's function as a cultivator and steward of God's bounty; the language is specific in its usage and not general, just as the passage as a whole concerns itself with God's relationship with man as opposed to the whole of Creation. Hence, to equate Chapter 2 with Chapter 1 as though they were meant to be competing accounts, rather than complementary, is a mistake at the very outset. Both Boice's commentary and Keil and Delitzsch's more scholarly tome both cover this in detail.

The appearance of 'contradictions' is not enough to substantiate true variance or discordance within the overall text. This is part and parcel of why higher criticism's methodology has been so laboriously critiqued within the last 50 years or so.

posts.com:
During the last months of his administration, an infuriated John Adams went around frantically appointing Federalist justices to stymie Thomas Jefferson. This included Chief Justice John Marshall, who lasted into the Jackson Administration and out-lived his own party as he continued to hand down Federalist decisions for over three decades.

Particularly irritating was Associate Justice Samuel Chase, who was so despised by Democratic-Republicans that they named wild dogs after him. Jefferson tried to have the temperamental, coarse-tongued Chase impeached and removed from the Supreme Court. However, Congress, during the impeachment proceedings, failed to find any evidence that he'd committed high crimes and misdemeanors, or was guilty of anything more than a loose tongue and conduct unbecoming of a Supreme Court justice. The impeachment attempt failed and Chase remained on the court until his death in 1811.

This was the first and last attempt to impeach a Supreme Court justice and its failure went aways to establishing the judiciary's independence.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>the ancient Greeks believed that XYZ

No, they probably didn't. Most things we think that the ancient Greeks believed comes from philosophers and other intellectuals, because they were the only ones who wrote stuff down. But those people did not represent wider Greek society or even the actual elites. They were outcasts that complained about how corrupt society was and praised virtues that were missing from it.

In Athens, the most intellectual city, the average citizen didn't even know the difference between the sophists and followers of Socrates, as evidenced by The Clouds by Aristophanes and Socrates' trial, where they just lumped him in with "those weird nerds that teach kids to talk their way out of debts or something".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14543404
Despite the huge size of the complex most residents had no idea what was going on. In many ways they had it better than a lot of Poles in other parts of Poland. The huge number of SS personnel and other German settlers required servants and many residents found employment and protection that way. My grandmother was a teenage girl during the war and she became a maid for a family of German settlers who actually treated her well, giving her all sorts of luxury items for her service. On the flipside a portion of the population was expelled to make space for the camp and some residents became more aware or less complicit than others and were smuggling medicine and food inside the camp or helping forced laborers escape.
Generally speaking the public was unaware of what was going on inside the camp until the later stages of the war. From 1942 to 1944 a lot of escapees wrote reports that eventually made their way to the Home Army, then the Polish government in exile, then the Allied governments and finally the press. This increased awareness eventually led Jewish communities in the US and Britain to advocate for bombing campaigns against the camp's railway infrastructure but the only raid that actually took place was against IG Farben works at the Monowitz subcamp

>>14543443
Auschwitz II originally started off as a POW camp, but it's purpose quickly changed
It wasn't a pure extermination camp in a sense that everyone who ended up at Birkenau would be gassed, but rather it served as both a giant distribution centre for the Reich's slave labor system as well as an extermination place for those who were deemed too useless to be a slave laborer. Many people (mainly Poles) were in Birkenau only for transit purposes. Out of those who remained not all of them were killed outright as the Auschwitz complex had its own labor requirements. Inmates were used to expand the camp, guard each other, sort through people's personal belongings or for work in various subcamps. So in this sense it wasn't a pure extermination camp, but industrial killing was without a shadow of a doubt one of Birkenau's functions

>>14551050
Wooden doors can be made gas tight if constructed sturdily enough, and with a sealing material between the slats, which these doors were. The preassure differences between the inside of the room and the outside of the room would have been equal; the only gas transfer the doors would have needed to counter was from diffusion. They did not need to be pressure-sealed hatches like what you see on submarines, for example.

Keep in mind also that poison gas killes based on its concentration. Even the presence of small leaks would not have hampered operation of the gas chamber. Consider how with carbon monoxide poisoning, some people in the building can die while others in a nearby room remain unharmed.

>>14566098

Sounds to me like you're taking an idiosyncratic interpretation of language roots and trying to force a connection where none really exists. The only proposed alternative meaning of any genuine merit is your El Shaddai rendering. James Montgomery Boice and others have noted that the term may originate from a Semitic term for bosom, which makes sense given the fertility blessings commonly sought from deities in the ANE. That this appellate is used of God is his dealings with Abraham is appropriate given the context of the covenant made concerning Canaan's future possession by the patriarch's offspring. The Biblical authors are essentially saying that God is the one who brings nourishment, and sustenance to the inhabitants of the earth, just as a mother does for her suckling child.

Of course, this is not the only suitable rendering of El Shaddai. As for the rest of your conjecture, I find no scholarly support for the bold-faced assertions you so cavalierly purport to prove. Might want to crack open a book.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Operation Barbarossa relied on the sole factor that the Red Army was going to be defeated in the initial months of the operation, and that the German military would then capture the country without any effective resistance.
It failed becase:
A: The germans had severely underestimated the sheer size of the Red Army.
B: The germans had severely underestimated the Red Army production capability
C: The germans had severely underestimated the Red Army ability to recover and to learn from its mistakes
D: The Germans had severely overestimated their own capabilities and conditions to conduct such a grand operation.

When Hitler said "we only need to kick in the door", he pretty perfectly described the emphasis of the entire operation.
Barbarossa was also poorly planned and was overoptimistic and did not take into account many decisive factors such as weather, hence why Barbarossa was delayed. It also did not take into account that the german forces were not mechanized to carry out the necessary pincer attacks. The majority of the army was powered by horses and infantry had to walk, leading to armored divisions constantly having to pull the breaks to let the infantry catch up, missing ample opportunity to prevent a Red army escape.

Something they also did not expect was the nature of the individual soviet soldier. It became a painful thorn for Germany that many russian soldiers refused to surrender despite being surrounded and cut off, situations western soldiers would ordinarily give up, and this added to the mounting german casualties and lost momentum.

Lend lease did not come into effect until much later and was more responsible for giving the Red Army offensive capabilities, altough they did recieve vital aid from Britain through the arctic convoys.

There are objective and subjective factors. posts.name: Anonymous

>>14561130

>>14561130
You are an idiot. Napoleon's army (1/6th of what the Wehrmacht sent to Russia) sourced almost all of their supplies locally, because almost all of their supply needs were food and fuel. Even shot could be sourced from captured Russian stocks, and shot was much less of a need weight wise than organic stuff.

Barbarossa, on the other hand, moved far more stuff. https://www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/Germany/HB/HB-6.html Check out section 4. An infantry division in combat required 1,100 metric tons of supply EVERY DAY. Barbarossa committed 153 divisions; and while not all of them were fighting every day of the operation, on any given day quite a lot of them were. German tonnage movement requirements were in the tens of thousands. Napoleon's quartermasters couldn't move anything close to that. And EVERY army of WW2 stuck to railroads whenever it could, and the ones that had to stray from them for any reason ran into problems almost immediately. Reliance on the Via Balbia made invading out of Libya and into Egypt a fucntional impossibility, and it also doomed the British to overextension and crushing defeat in the aftermath of Compass and Crusader, for all of their greater mechanization. The single biggest thing stopping the rout of German forces in France in August and September 1944 was the Transportation plan's damage to railroads that hobbled the Anglo-American forces. Soviet doctrine called for engineering units to build railroads to support advances if there weren't any nearby ones to appropriate. The Japanese offensives into China ran into immediate and remarkable difficulties once they seized the railroad networks up and down the east coast and tried to push west into far less developed territory.

>Railroads only help when you're actually near them
meant that WW2 armies stayed near railroads, at least when they wanted to concentrate into meaningfully large formations.

I agree that measuring space programs by their unique accomplishments is a better metric. The Moon landing is the most significant and high profile example of this, but it's not the only one. For example, the US has sent probes to every single planet in the solar system, including/even Pluto, while the Soviets only ever explored Venus and Mars. American exploration of Mars is also undeniably superior to the Soviet program. The Soviets had one "successful" landing, before losing communications with the lander some 20 seconds later. In comparison, the first American lander was operational for some 6 years and American rovers have been active on the Martian surface for the past few decades.

All in all, the US has an edge in the exploration of every major celestial body in the solar system besides Venus. But it's not like being the only ones to explore Mercury, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune, and all of their respective moons is something that should be considered noteworthy.

I can't be bothered to write a full reply to this awful comieboo drivel so I'm going to just copy and paste an explanation I found elswhere, like a true American

When I was in 2nd grade, we had this class project where we would build a tower out of straws. One other team in the class built upwards as fast as they could. They would go straight up from wherever they were, and if one part started to slouch or tip over they'd fix that part and then go back to going straight up. Our team made sure that everything was solid; we had a good, consistent, repeatable design of cubes with cross beams. We wouldn't built the next layer unless the current layer was strong. The other team was the first to 2 feet, then the first to 3 feet, then the first to 4 feet, but at some point the fact that their entire tower was half measures meant that they couldn't add anything to the top; regardless of what they added to the top, their entire everything was too weak to just reinforce one or two parts of it. The best way for them to make progress was to throw everything away and start over from scratch. So our team was the first to 5 feet.

Von Braun's personal mission was to colonize Mars; the official mission of the US space program was to land a manned mission on the Moon. The mission of the Soviet space program was to beat the US space program at everything.

The US had smaller (in terms of size and weight) nukes than the Soviet Union did. This meant that the US ICBMs were much smaller than Soviet ICBMs. When it came to converting ICBMs into space science vessels, the Soviet Union were already a step ahead. The R-7 was an enormous ICBM. So Sputnik, Yuri Gagarin, etc were all launched on R-7s.

The US knew they'd need a large crew and some sort of orbital rendezvous to make a moon landing work. So they built the larger Gemini mission that could support two people. 1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14564497
The Soviet Union wanted to beat the US to a multiple crewed mission, so they took their single person R-7, removed a bunch of stuff (including some essential life support systems) and put another person in it. The USSR did beat the US to that milestone. The US mission was a stepping stone but not a milestone; the Soviet mission was a milestone but not a stepping stone.

The US had to learn how to rendezvous two spacecraft in order to make the moon mission work. So they set out to start doing that. The Soviet Union wanted to beat them, so they launched one R-7 to orbit, waited for the orbit to line up with the ground station, and launched another R-7 into an identical orbit. They were able to get within 3 miles of each other, at which points their orbits diverged; bada bing, bada boom, rendezvous! US beaten. But the US needed to actually connect them together. Remember the larger Gemini capsules? It also had substantially more fuel for maneuvering. So Gemini 6 and 7 were able to maneuver to within a few feet of each other and stay there for 20 minutes. Gemini 8 had the docking adapter and was able to actually connect to another spacecraft.

The US knew they'd need an absolute monster of a rocket to land on the moon, so they started designing the F-1 engine in 1957 and the Saturn V in 1962. The engine and the rocket were absolute fucking monsters, totally in excess of the needs of the time. The US hadn't even launched a thing into orbit in 1957 when the F-1 first hit the drawing board. The Soviets didn't see the need for a rocket that big; there was no milestone for 'big rocket' to beat the Americans to, and the R-7 was fine, so they didn't build one.

By 1965, it was clear that the next milestone after rendezvous was the moon, so focus turned to that. The US was already almost done building the Saturn V. And the Soviet Union looked to scale the R-7 up again, but--it wouldn't work. 1.5/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14564501
The R-7 was already as big as it could get with the technology of the day. So they had to throw away everything and try to rebuild from scratch with the N-1. The N-1 hit the drawing board in 1965. The Saturn V would have its first launch in 1967. The N-1 prototype hit the launch pad in 1969 and exploded shortly after takeoff. The 2nd, 3rd, and 4th and final launch attempts also failed. It was just too rushed.

Basically the US thought of space as a series of stepping stones; each thing has to be in service of the next thing. The Soviet Union thought of the space race as a series of milestones; each thing has to be the first. It's just a philosophy that doesn't engender itself to a decades long space exploration program.

Derivatives of the R-7 still fly today, by the way. The Soyuz, the workhorse of the Russian space program, is an R-7 derivative. 2/2

Landing something on Venus isn't very difficult, since having a thick atmosphere means you just need a parachute. Actually, the Soviet lander had its parachute fail and it still survived the landing at terminal velocity. The challenge is making it last long enough on the surface to justify the cost. Since the material science wasn't really there yet, NASA decided that it would be a waste of money to spend a few billion dollars on a lander which would only survive on the surface for a few minutes.

But surviving for a few minutes is good by Soviet standards, since that Mars lander you mentioned transmitted data for some 20 seconds. The American equivalents lasted years, and were succeeded by (actual) rovers which gave invaluable data.

>>14560821
>retarded number of currently existing small engines instead of having new, appropriately sized engines designed
Building a large engine is not easy at all, and would have pushed the delivery date far past what would have been needed to beat NASA. The soviets were extremely curious about how Rocketdyne managed to build the F-1 engine for the Saturn V, when to their knowledge the exhaust instability should have made such a big engine impossible.
The answer: Rocketdyne would detonate small explosives around a test engine as it fired, giving them enough data on the engine's reaction to pressure changes to develop countermeasures against the instability.
The development cycle of the F-1 took eight years until a flight-ready model was ready for use. They destroyed a LOT of test engines, but it didn't matter because they had all the funding they could ask for.
The N1 by comparison was designed, built, and tested in a fraction of that time, on a much smaller budget. It failed mostly because Korolev died and the bureau didn't have the funding to test engines before flight. The infighting between design bureaus didn't help either. It absolutely could have worked.

>>14562607
Mostly because European settlement is a little over two hundred years old, especially when we're considering the frontier outside the state capitals.
It falling solely under British control too prevented differing approaches towards colonisation, interaction with the natives, and the differing cultural diffusion as the Americas saw.
Moreover, the fact the Aboriginals essentially peaked at hunter-gathering and didn't develop much in sense of statecraft, means Australian history isn't as colourful as others.
There were no great conquests of settled civilisations as there were in the Americas, the frontier wars were streamlined in comparison to the Americas due to the larger technological advantage and the lack of horses the Aboriginals had, and mostly consisted of pacifying wandering bands, and dispossessing them of their land. Towards the end, they'd be rounded up onto missions.
There's still history, it's just that you don't find it interesting, and admittedly, I think it's a fair comment to say it isn't as interesting as others, but there's still bits and pieces to enjoy and discover.

So it's not like there was a linear development of the Australian identity, it was very scattered until we had to come together in 1901.

All "Australia" really meant was that the Federal Government would control coinage, the army, rail and taxes, everything else was left to the states as it used to be. The reason why Gallipolli and the ANZAC legend is said to be the founding of Australia is because that was our first time on the world stage as a country and we not only proved ourselves, but developed a famous national character that defined who we were.

>>14563508
The reason they had such difficulty with the turks is because they really had no answer to them out on the Anatolian plateau. Emperors could take cities from them, only for those cities to be isolated and picked off by the nomads on the open plateau.

They couldn't beat the turks in a straight fight by any other means than overwhelming numbers. At Dorylaeum that's how the crusaders managed it, for instance. The Byzantines did have a chance, though, because as /his/ constantly refuses to understand medieval statecraft wasn't as simple as winning this or that battle. Alexios, John and Manuil Komnenos all knew the way to defeat the turks and reclaim the plateau - to control Antioch and surround them. Alexios, John and Manuil all in turn failed to retake Antioch, despite coming extremely close, and then Manuil focused on Italy instead of Anatolia long enough for the turks to unite. When Manuil failed at Myriokephalon, he wasted his last shot, and the largest army the empire had raised in centuries.

When he died, the collapse of imperial authority met with a strong turkic state. Throw in the cataclysmic accident of 1204 and that's it. After that there really was no chance.

People here really don't understand the Byzantine state, or the medieval state in general, because of spending so much time reading Herodotus or watching youtube videos of famous battles. That focus on heroic generals winning glorious battles is why no-one seems to understand why the Byzantines didn't just conquer their lands back - surely it should be as simple as sending out some new Belisarius with a big army and conquering east like Alexander did. They didn't have the money or the connections or the manpower. They didn't expand much south of Antioch/Laodicea into the Levant even under the Macedonians because they couldn't hold the territory and it wasn't worth the pay of a garrison to try.

some of the main points of the British North America/Quebec Act of 1774 was that A) the Canadians were allowed to keep the seigneurial system of exploitation instead of having their lands reorganized under the canton system used by most british holdings, and B) the British would allow the Catholic Church not only to practice, proselytize and promote the Catholic Faith in the Province of Quebec, but would also allow them to collect the tithe, which essentially meant that unlike in say Great Britain and the Thirteen Colonies, organized bishopric holdings were still a thing.

>to limit the amount of anglophonic influence on the larger quebecois population by building new centers away from Montreal
>to begin the exploitation of raw resources, along with arable lands, further away from the valley of the Saint-Lawrence, AKA proto-industrialization

"Any individual's death diminished the collective power of his or her lineage, clan, village, and nation, provoking powerful and angry bursts of grief, especially by female relatives. Natives feared that their dead would linger about the village, inflicting disease and misfortune unless appeased with loud and expressive mourning. To draw the bereaved out of their agony and to encourage dead spirits to proceed to their afterlife, neighbors staged condolence rituals with feasts and presents. The best present of all was a war captive meant to replace the dead.
To appease grief, to restore power, and to build their own status, Iroquois warriors conducted "mourning wars" in which they sought prisoners from their enemies. The chiefs distributed the prisoners to grieving matrilineages, whose elder women decided their fate: Adoption or death. The matrons usually adopted women and children, who were more readily assimilated. Captive men more often faced death by torture, especially if they had received some crippling wound. Inflicting death as slowly and painfully as possible, the Iroquois tied their victim to a stake, and villagers of both genders and all ages took turns wielding knives, torches, and red-hot pokers systematically to torment and burn him to death. The ceremony was a contest between the skills of the torturers and the stoic endurance of the victim, who manifested his own power, and that of his people, by insulting his captors and boasting of his accomplishments in war. After the victim died, the women butchered his remains, cast them into cooking kettles, and served the stew to the entire village, so that all could be bound together in absorbing the captive's power. By practicing ceremonial torture and cannibalism, the Iroquois promoted group cohesion, hardened their adolescent boys for the cruelties of war, and dramatized their contempt for outsiders."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14564485
You're understanding of events is flawed.

The failure of Germany's spring offensives deeply damaged their offensive capabilities hence why each subsequent operation following Operation Michael had to be smaller in scope and more modest in their aims.

By the time of July, Ludendorff was running on fumes - launching desperate offensives from badly overextended lines utilizing increasingly exhausted and demoralized soldiers. These overextended lines invited counterattacks and Germany's limited reserves made such counterattacks perilous for the state of the front. Germany's tactics were also becoming predictable after months of attacks coupled with the information the Allies were able to extract from aerial reconnaissance missions and defecting soldiers. The final German attack in July saw the Allies clearing out their front trenches prior to the German bombardment, rendering it ineffective, before troops ran into 37 French, 4 British, 2 Italian, and 2 U.S. Divisions on that date. It's incorrect to claim the U.S. stopped them - unless you mean via loans to the Allies - or that Germany would have been able to realistically march on Paris by that point.

The Allies would have been able to withstand the Kaiserschlact without American troops. However, it's possible numerical parity would have existed afterwards without American reinforcements giving Germany something more of a negotiating point.

However, I feel embarking on the Kaiserschlact was a mistake from the get-go given the way it depleted German reserves, exhausted their troops, required the abandonment of their defensive positions on the Hindenburg Line, and worsened the situation on other fronts as a result of German troops needing to be redeployed from them.

Once again, perhaps Germany would have still had the ability to negotiate without American involvement but their negotiating position would still likely be worse had they embarked on a defensive strategy, focusing on other fronts.

>>14553430
I thought up a small argument against image veneration myself.

1. One of their claims is that Christ's incarnation, God taking upon himself an image, means that we can show veneration to God through man-made images. But we can only show veneration through a man-made image, not worship. But Christ can be worshiped through his actual physical presence, if he were literally present. So there isn't a direct analogy between Christ's body and a statue or painting. They're necessarily in different categories.

2. If only veneration can be shown to a man-made image of Christ, this means that the only way to worship Christ is without a man-made image. You can never worship him through it or you would be committing idolatry. So the use of images requires you to show less honor to Christ than he is actually due.

Interestingly, many early Christian apologists appealed to the aniconism of the ancients in justifying Christianity. Heraclitus rejected idols as well, and Rome was well-known to have rejected all idols for the first century of its existence. It is like Romans 1 teaches, people exchange God for creation.

Numa Pompilius:
> His opinion, also, of images is very agreeable to the doctrine of Pythagoras; who conceived of the first principle of being as transcending sense and passion, invisible and incorrupt, and only to be apprehended by abstract intelligence. So Numa forbade the Romans to represent God in the form of man or beast, nor was there any painted or graven image of a deity admitted amongst them for the space of the first hundred and seventy years, all which time their temples and chapels were kept free and pure from images; to such baser objects they deemed it impious to liken the highest, and all access to God impossible, except by the pure act of the intellect.

>>14553604
Panagia may also refer to a prosphoron (Ἄρτος της Παναγίας, Ártos tēs Panagías, "Bread of the All-Holy") which is solemnly blessed in honor of the Theotokos during the Divine Liturgy (see Prosphora for details). From this loaf, a large triangle in honour of the Theotokos is cut and placed on the diskos (paten) during the Liturgy of Preparation. The remainder of the loaf is blessed over the Holy Table (altar) during the hymn Axion Estin, just before the blessing of the antidoron. The priest makes the Sign of the Cross with the Panagia over the Sacred Mysteries (consecrated Body and Blood of Christ) as he says, "Great is the name of the Holy Trinity."
https://www.liquisearch.com/panagia/blessed_bread

Likewise wrt Clement of Alexandria, if the claim rests on his remarks in the Paedagogus quoted here: https://russianicons.wordpress.com/tag/clement-of-alexandria/

Likewise Irenaeus to the extent the claim rests on Against Heresies, I, 25.6 (https://www.newadvent.org/fathers/0103125.htm), given that those remarks are plainly directed at an idolatrous practice by a gnostic group. It goes beyond the sense of the passage to infer from it a condemnation of the veneration of icons in a Christian context.

>Irenaeus in condemning the Carpocrates isn’t condemning them for having art work per se of things in heaven, earth or under the earth. He doesn’t invoke biblical language as read to prohibit all image making. Nor is there here an unconditional condemnation of veneration of images. Irenaeus doesn’t say that veneration is evil and therefore what the Carpocrates are doing is evil...

>There do seem to be three things that have warranted Irenaeus’ condemnation. First, they claim to have an image made by Pontius Pilate of Jesus. They seemingly use this to bolster their claim to apostolic authenticity.

>Second, that they set up this image of Jesus along with various philosophers... This implication seems to be that Jesus is one of many men of wisdom...

>Third, that they have other modes of honoring these images [that] are essentially the same as those found among the pagans for honoring their gods.

In sum, the sources do not make out the claim.

Catholic doctrine is that when Adam was created, his natural state was not sufficient for him to perfectly obey the law and thus merit eternal life, so God infused with him an superadded gift of grace (donum superadditum) which, if Adam cooperated with it, would enable him to perfectly obey God. Adam failed and was cut off from this grace, and so are all of us through original sin, but we regain it through baptism.

In contrast, Protestants generally hold that Adam was created with the ability to obey God and merit eternal life as a natural ability, as simply a part of his creation. This is an integral part of Pelagianism. Protestants are not total Pelagians in that they do not extend this ability into the post-fall pre-baptismal state. But this concept, that pre-fall man had the natural ability to perfectly obey God, is Pelagian.

(cont.)
I'll give my own argument in favor of icon veneration, both to defend the practice and attempt to protect against this. I'm only knowledgeable enough to attempt this from a Catholic perspective, so this may not necessarily work for Orthodoxy.

1. Regarding the early patristic evidence, we should take several things into account:

a.) They have an overarching concern with distinguishing Christians from pagans, which ceased to apply after several centuries. The early total condemnations of images have to be reconciled with slightly later fathers such as Gregory the Great who advocate for at least a didactic use of images.

b.) In some of the condemnatory texts, such as Epiphanius, Eusebius, Origen, we find an appeal to common practice, that images are forbidden and disallowed by all Christians. From the archaeological evidence we can tell this is not true. We have the catacomb paintings, the house church at Dura-Europos, etc. Some of these figure were well-traveled and well-educated so why would they make this claim? The situation ends up being rather strange on account of this.

(1/2)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14564453
(cont.)
2. On account of point 1., I would argue that the use of images thus falls into a category we can label as "unclear" or "disputed." To elaborate,

a.) We can make a comparison to the canon of scripture. The status of the deuterocanonical books was not settled by any patristic consensus, and we can find fathers who disallow them from the canon, or from the canon proper (as a rule of faith). The matter was left to lie until being definitively settled at Trent due to the provocation of the Reformation.

b.) I say "unclear" because the creation of images of Christ and the saints, which we know did occur at early dates, is an act of veneration in itself. We paint or sculpt those whom we wish to honor, and we can remember them through reference to their image. And an image of someone is understood in some sense as being representative of their person. Unless motivated by iconoclastic destruction or some unique motive, one would understand the destruction of an image as an act of disrespect to the one depicted, for example. It is but one step from here to understand an act of homage paid to an image to indicate that one honors the prototype.

(2/3 -- will need one more post, apologies)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14564459
(cont.)
c.) I would thus say that the veneration of icons, at least in the sense that Nicaea II has been received by the Latin Church, is incipient within the creation of images of Christ and the saints. As the concept is incipient, it can thus be a legitimate place of development rather than reversal of course. And the early objectors can be understood contextually, or ignored in their erroneous statements, as the matter was forced to be clarified due to the provocation of iconoclasm. This incipient element also allows the acceptance of Nicaea II's claim of the ancient veracity of the practice, and that it is not a novelty.

d.) No such thing can be said for homosexuality, which has a fully developed teaching against it, accepted clearly and universally through the history of the church, which rules out any form of the practice; any development can only occur from what is incipient within it, and thus any "development" into acceptance of the practice could only signify contradiction.

>they bring a 'strange fire' into the sanctuary. Have to admit I don't know what that is, it's very vague.
It means something other than the specific incense that they were suppose to use. Burning anything other than that in that place would be a failure to observe the law, and "strange" just means it isn't the specific incense they were supposed to use. The basic point with "strange fire" is that, whatever it was, it wasn't the right thing that they were already told had to be used. See Exodus 30:8-9, 31-38.

>>14560847
There are definitely symbolic applications of a lot of the laws that involve ritual purity, which is one of the main parts of what is known as the ceremonial law. Ceremonial was one of the three main parts of the Mosaic law along with the moral law and civil law. The ceremonial law, by the way, is the part that is considered to be fulfilled in the New Testament by Christ; it includes things like dietary laws, a specific religious calendar, animal sacrifices, and anything to do with maintaining ritual purity. Whereas the moral law still applies and the civil law is still a good idea (but has to be enforced by a righteous government with courts rather than by vigilantes).

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14562373
>What would moral laws and civil laws be, for example?
Moral/civil laws are not linked to the Levitical animal sacrifice system or calendar observance or anything ceremonial regarding ritual purity (since that involves all the rules of whether or not you are allowed to be in the tabernacle/temple).

The difference between moral and civil laws is basically who they pertain to. The moral law applies to individuals, for example "thou shalt not kill," "honor thy father and mother," and "thou shalt not covet" from the Ten Commandments are examples of these.

The civil law are laws that have certain defined penalties attached. So the part of the law where penalties such as stoning or some other penalty are applied are the "civil law." For instance, the death penalty for being a sodomite, and forcing a man who fornicates with a woman to marry, would be examples of this.

Sometimes the two are intertwined, for instance the part in Leviticus that says, "Thou shalt not lie with mankind, as with womankind: it is abomination." This statement is part of the moral law. But the part where it prescribes the punishment for this, saying they shall be stoned, is the civil law. So basically the moral law is something you are expected to follow individually, and the civil law is the part that the government should enforce, such as executing sodomites and the like. The purpose of the moral/civil division is pretty obvious, because you don't just go around accusing someone of a crime and then appoint yourself as the judge, jury and executioner. That part has to be enforced by a righteous government. Neither the moral law nor the civil law are changed by the New Testament, only the ceremonial law is handled differently (not technically abolished), since Christ Himself fulfills that now (c.f. Col. 2:16-17), ever since He lived a perfect life in accordance with the entire Law and didn't break a single rule even once, thereby fulfilling it.

>Pulling out of your dead brother's wife instead of knocking her up.
Not really anything strange about it from a cultural perspective. Marriage in those days was primarily seen as a duty and a way to maintain family lineage through children. Marriage for 'love' wasn't really a thing, but family was everything, especially when it came to inheritance and property rights.

So a man who dies early with no kids is in danger of ending his family line and screwing over his widow and ownership of family property. Having the next nearest relative of the dead man get his wife pregnant was actually a BENEFIT and SAFETY NET for the wife, because it 1) kept the woman in a stable household and off the streets, since State Welfare wasn't really a thing then, and 2) it preserved the family line and property since the new children were considered as the children of the dead man, even if technically fathered by a relative.

The entire book of Ruth was literally nothing but this scenario playing out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
At a National Security Council meeting in March 1953, two months into the new administration, Eisenhower remarked to the vice president "Dick, what are you going to do this summer?" "Whatever you say," was Nixon's reply. "Well, I think you should take a trip to the Far East. Take Pat along." Ike didn't mean for Nixon to just take a casual vacation of course, he meant serious diplomatic business--he was getting concerned that the US was not paying sufficient attention to East Asia; Truman had little interest in the region and he was not well-versed in it himself. Nixon however was a natural. His California upbringing and Navy service in the Pacific had enhanced his interest in the region. Unlike many in the US diplomatic corps, he understood that Asia might play a bigger role in the post-WWII world than Europe.

But for the time being, eleven of the 19 countries on his itinerary were controlled by the UK and France, neither of whom were especially enthusiastic about a high-ranking American official visiting their colonies. The French were obstructive, while the British Foreign Office sent a reply stating "We must hope that the president's goodwill intentions in sending Senator (sic) Nixon will not backfire. His record as vice president has been rather better than might have been feared, but we must hope that he will be tactful. Is he leaving his Spaniel behind?"
posts.filename: richard nixon and his party in malaysia 1953

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The British did rather quickly upgrade their opinion of Nixon, and in a dispatch from Kuala Lumpur on October 27, Field Marshal Sir George Templer sent Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden a message stating "...the vice president is an extremely nice man in every way. He has got charming manners and in fact he was the very reverse of everything we expected from reading the news reports of the American election. He is easy in his conversations and gets along extremely well with the many Asians he met. I was really very impressed with Nixon indeed. He seemed potentially to me to be a much bigger man than Adlai Stevenson, whom we met a few years ago."

One week later in Singapore, Nixon made a favorable impression with Commissioner General for Southeast Asia Malcolm MacDonald. "I was agreeably impressed by Mr. Nixon's general knowledge of the situation of Southeast Asia, of the mood and suspectabilities of the Asian nations and of broad Asian problems. He seemed to me to have exactly the right approach to the Asians and their difficulties to have very sensible view on the policies which we in the West should pursue towards them."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A noticeable change in Nixon's viewpoint concerned China--while he had attacked the PRC no-holds-barred during the 1950 and '52 election campaigns, now he was saying that Chiang Kai-Shek was a discredited loser and proposed ways to pry Beijing away from her alliance with the USSR. MacDonald proposed various ways to do this including joint efforts to maintain peace on the Korean peninsula. As MacDonald said in a dispatch, "Mr. Nixon said that he too agreed that if the Chinese became more reasonable about the Korean peace talks, we should seek to help them further. It might be possible to contemplate their entry into the UN, although American public opinion would make this difficult. He was personally not unsympathetic to the general notion. Perhaps the first thing, before any political concessions were made to Beijing, would be to try and improve trade with China." This 1953 report was the first intimation of Nixon's open-minded thinking on China, which took 19 more years to bear fruit.

During six days in French Indochina, Nixon came to increasingly doubt the chance of a French victory for the main reason that the haughty French continued to treat the Vietnamese as colonial subjects. He surprised his hosts by spending equal time with the French officers and Vietnamese enlisted men. He sampled their respective menus of monkey stew and boeuf au Bourguignonne washed down with Algerian red wine, a gastronomy that symbolized a sharply divided loyalty and culture, which Nixon saw as manifesting itself into open French contempt for their Vietnamese subjects. Publicly Nixon supported French efforts to win the war against the Vietminh, but privately believed it was hopeless. He also mused that Ho Chi Minh seemed more appealing and popular than any of the anti-communist leaders in Vietnam.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Many of the countries and capitals Nixon was going to had never been visited by an American vice president or president. In Tokyo, him and Pat were the Emperor's first official foreign guests since before WWII. Remarking that the US shouldn't have insisted on Japanese disarmament back in the 1930s, he also proposed rearming Japan, a suggestion anathema to many Americans coming so soon as it did after the war. This trial balloon, which had been greenlighted beforehand by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, made national and international headlines. Nixon was greeted by huge Japanese crowds chanting "Niku-sun! Niku-sun!"

A lot of the Nixons' moves on their Asia trip were new. Pat visited schools, orphanages, and hospitals, and the vice president determined to get out among the common people instead of limiting himself to cocktail dinners with state officials. In India, Nixon had a less than friendly meeting with the pro-Soviet Nehru and the highlight of his visit was a meeting with the guru Rajagopalachari, a Gandhi colleague. Rajiji, as he was known in short, received Nixon on a straw mat in Madras, clad only in sandals and a loincloth and the two spent the afternoon discussing spiritual matters; especially reincarnation and predestination. Nixon filled a couple pages with notes from the visit and in his memoirs 36 years later said that many things he learned from the guru made their way into speeches of his.

Among the political leaders Nixon met included Chiang Kai-Shek, the Shah of Iran, Robert Menzies, Sukarno, Ayub Khan, Prince Souvanna Phouma, Lee Kuan-Yew, and U Thant. Some of these men would still be in office and play a part in his foreign policy as president two decades later.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The only country where Nixon had serious business was Korea, where he gave Syngman Rhee a letter from Eisenhower demanding assurances that the 78 year old South Korean president would refrain from future armed hostilities on the peninsula. Rhee was evasive and said he would inform Eisenhower before committing to any promises. This was a problem for sure, and it devolved into drawn-out meetings where Rhee came off as a grandfather schooling his grandson as he told Nixon that it was wise to be unpredictable in dealing with communists. But ultimately he conceded and promised to not attack North Korea on his own. Nixon sent word back to Washington that Rhee seemed trustworthy enough, and US economic aid to Seoul could commence.

The Nixons arrived in Washington on December 14, after a 70 day trek. It had been hard and the Nixons were exhausted, sleep-deprived, had lost weight, and were suffering from bug bites. Pat recalled "It was the hardest trip we ever made. Dick lost ten pounds from dysentery, and in those days before air conditioning he had to shake the damp from his pants every night. We were glad to be back home." Eisenhower sent a warm, gushing letter that read:

"Dear Dick. Proud as I am of the record you and Pat established on your recent visit to a number of Asian countries, I must say I'm glad you returned home. We, by which I mean all the principle figures in the administration, have missed your wise counsel, your energetic support, and your exemplary dedication to the service of your country. On the purely personal side, it was fine to see you both looking so well after the rigors of a trip that must have taxed the strength of even such young and vigorous people as yourselves. I look forward to some quiet opportunity when I can hear a real recital of your adventures and accomplishments."
